Spectacular!! Bottle from a trade. Thanks! Poured into a snifter at home. Opaque, jet black pour with a thin mocha head. Some lacing throughout. Strong aromas of coffee, dark chocolate, cocoa nibs, vanilla, roasted malts. The taste was quite impressive with dark chocolate, bourbon, oak, roasted malts and coffee. Very slightly vanilla sweetness. Full body, a little oily. Good carbonation. I couldn¬ít get enough of this! Soft and creamy on the palette. Finish lingers with bourbon and chocolate. I WANT MORE!!

Opaque black, small beige lacing. Bourbon, fresh espresso, vanilla, milk chocolate, wood, and a little dark fruit. Good mix of bittersweet flavors, which becomes more bitter over time. Smooth, creamy, and full-bodied. Lingering black coffee finish
Bottle thanks to steve-o. Thanks! Aroma is chocolate and coffee, taste is the same. oily mouthfeel, nice beer.

Bottle at FoCo Stout Tasting 2013, with friends. Pour is pitch black with a small brown head and good lacing. Caramel, toffee, cocoa, light bread, coffee, a hint of cherries, bourbon, and raisins in the aroma. Taste is sweet dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, toffee, sweet malt, bready, bourbon, toffee, figs, and raisins with a light burn on the backend. Slick mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Really nice stuff, but still not as good as the original.

2012

Pours black, red edges, minimal tan head.

Smell big red fruit, bit of coconut. Sweet. 

Taste sweet coconut and big vanilla, oaky barrel, bit of coco and roast, coffee has faded.

Mid to fuller body

Very nice

Bottle 2012 vintage shared by Mike at the Thursday mini-tasting. Thanks! Pours opaque black with a small brown head and decent lacing. Aroma is BOURBON, cocoa, roasted malts. Flavor is medium sweet, medium bitter, boozy. Medium body, hot, very whiskey forward. I am amazed this beer scores so well here.

Black, brown, tan head, decent lacing. chocolate, brown sugar aroma. Whiskey flavors come through strongly, charred oak, coffee. Kind of wrecks the beer honestly even though I¬ím a whiskey drinker. Strong after taste of ash or tobacco.

Aroma of chocolate and coffee. With hints of vanilla and bourbon. Taste is boozy Bourbon With dark chocolate and coffee immediately following. Full, thick and viscous with Moderate carbonation. Like a bourbon soaked chocolate cake with coffee icing. Only knock is that it is a little bit alcoholic and too warming. Almost hot Otherwise great stuff. Thanks Justin for the bottle!

Bottle. Opaque black liquid with small to medium tan head. Aroma of coffee, wood, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, toffee, caramel, raw sugar and bread. Taste is light to medium sweet and light to medium bitter with notes of coffee, raw sugar, bourbon, wood and vanilla. Medium to full bodied with low to medium carbonation. Really, really good.

Thanks to Matt for sharing this bottle for our BA, Kopi, and Vietnamese trio tasting. Appearance is dark, nearly black, no real head -- you know, barrel-aged imperial stouty. We¬íve already dug into the double black tonight, which skews the scale of "thick, viscous, motor oil" descriptors, but even without that for comparison I wouldn¬ít call it thick. Aroma is "speedway" (nice to have already rated one for reference purposes, isn¬ít it? I¬ím going to need to explore the use of rating citations.) plus oxidation, vanilla, and oak. Slick texture, full body. A lot of sweetness, very little bitterness in the finish, some nice alcohol warming. Nice beer, I definitely prefer it to the base speedway.

750mL bottle from Shane. Thanks! 2011 release.

A: Pours a perfect black with a foamy dark head that dies very quickly.

N:heavy bourbon, vanilla, caramel, prunes, honey, milk chocolate, some coffee, and hinsts of raspberry and almond. 

T: Hefty coffee bitterness with a lot of wood and char. There¬ís minimal sweetness. Not as intense or delicious as previous vintages; in fact, I wouldn¬ít recommend this.

M: Medium heavy body that¬ís coating and has an overabundance of alcohol. 

O: Not a great vintage at all. The 2009 I had was far better. This got a few more points when it got warmer, but by the end, I really tired of it. Sad.

750ml bottle from Vinmonopolet Kvadrat. Aroma is roasted chocolate and coffee malts, espresso, molasses and bourbon. Pours black with a small head and good lacing. Flavor matches aroma and is very smooth for 12% strong ass brew that Speedway is. Palate is sticky. An excellent Imperial Stout, but doesnt beat Evil Twin - Even More Jesus

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2014 √Ñntligen l√§ge att √∂ppna denna raritet som st√•tt i k√§llaren ett tag nu och lurat. √Örg√•ng 2012. (Trade with Heyta. Thanks man!). Lite darrig p√• handen vid √∂ppnandet, som v√§ntat. Wow! tung doft av bourbon i doften. Dominerar i princip hela doftbilden. Underbart kr√§mig. √Ñven i smakbilden √§r bourbon oerh√∂rt tydlig. Och parallellt med en vanlig Speedway kan man knappast tro att det √§r samma √∂l i grunden. Oerh√∂rt balanserad. V√§rmde upp smakl√∂karna med 2-3 stouts f√∂re denna, vilket nog var bra. Kan nog upplevas som lite v√§l tung att dra direkt. 

Rerate: 2012a
Choklad och bourbon. Elegant och delikat. Tung men utan spritighet. Fantastik. Snacka om v√§rldsklass.

Bottle, 2013 vintage, 10/12/2013. Pours thick black, bubbly tan head dies to a smooth cream on the surface, sheets of lacing left behind. Aroma is fluffy chocolate caramel brownie, light cocoa syrup notes, roast coffee, vanilla coconut, rich caramel bourbon. Taste is creamy chocolate, dark coffee notes, vanilla coconut, roast bitterness melding with bourbon. Thick, creamy body with a bit of heat, yet overall smooth and decadent. Quite nice, did not fail to impress.

Gold marked bottle (2012) opened 10/4/13. Pours thick black, fast dissipating head. Nose is big coffee, bourbon and oak, and dark chocolate. Huge chocolate, and perfect marriage of coffee and oak. Truly amazing.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2014 Bottle: Thanks, Kevin! Silky, black body with only some dark brown at the extremities. The tan cap is a shade darker than the original Speedway¬ís and it dissolves a little quicker as well. Powerful aroma with huge barrel qualities; soft oak, vanilla, bourbon - slightly grainy and raw - dark fudge, and a mild hint of coffee. Coffee is quite muzzled here, compare to regular Speedway. Creamy, sexy smooth body with flavors of bourbon and vanilla up front, followed by light coconut, dense fudge, and some dark fruit and anise-like sweetness. The coffee is very understated on the palate as the bourbon character shines through, a bit unrefined. Very good beer, but it may just be a tad over the top. Though this beer is still delicious, it is not an improvement over the base, in my opinion.
Bottle: Re-rate thanks to Chris. Much more maple syrup on the nose than I remember, huge barrel presence but not as overwhelming this time around. Beautifully smooth, actually. Vanilla, wood, bourbon, maple, chocolate, molasses, just a little bit of coffee towards the finish.
Bottle sampled at RBSG. From notes. Vanilla with chocolate and coffee. Super boozy, even for 12%. Would love to drink this again.

2013 Bottle. Pours thick deep black with a big mocha head. Aroma is bitter chocolate, roasted malts, big coffee, faint vanilla and oak and very little bourbon. Taste is coffee, chocolate, roasted malt and some vanilla and oak. Balanced, creamy, full bodied beer. I prefer the original Speedway to the barrel aged version. This beer was a slight disappointment as I thought the barrel aging would have improved this beer. Still a really great beer however, the original takes the gold medal for me.
Zwanze Day 2013. Pours pure black grey lacing. Aroma is big chocolate malt bourbon. Taste bourbon chocolate malt more malt finishes long and smooth tasty malt.

Sweet and glorious. Many thanks to Dave for sharing this bottle four ways. Aroma is sticky toffee, bourbon, chocolate, and espresso. Pours black with a small tan head (I half expected no carbonation). Taste is nice and sweet with toffee Heath bar, cherry, vanilla, chocolate, espresso and tootsie roll. Just fantastic. Wish there was just a little more roast flavor and a little less heat but otherwise perfect.

Bottle at home, thanks to MJ for the trade, it even passed the Sue test who had a small glass !!! 01/09/13.
Pours pitch black with a good sized tan head that clears to a swirl.
Nose is luxurious chocolate malts, light coffee notes, burnt sugar, stewed raisens, subtle bourbon notes.
Taste comprises decadent chocolate, subtle coffee notes, brown sugars, oaky bourbon whiff.
Full bodied, fine carbonation, lightly warming alcohol but very easy drinking for the ABV.
Top draw impy, this one does not disappoint !!! Alcohol is well integrated making it an easy drinking affair, sweet but balanced, christ my girlfriend drank a snifter - was kind of hoping she¬íd pour it back in my glass !!!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Dark brown with medium to small head. Aroma of wood, bourbon, roasted coffee malts. Taste of roasted malts, coffee, wood. Warm alcohol aftertaste.
Very dark reddish brown beer that looks pitch back in the glass. Very nice mixture of roasted malts, coffee and some woodish liqour. Lovely sweet smooth brew.

Bottle. The pour is dark. The aroma is sweet sweet bourbon. The taste is a little harsh on the bourbon but solid overall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at RBSG. Pour is black with tan head. Tons of booze, vanilla and chocolate on the nose. A burnt caramel flavor, comes through on the tongue, vanilla, chocolate. Really syrupy and thick, lingered on the roof of my mouth. Awesome.
Thanks to a friend I was able to enjoy this beer. The coffee in this beer came out very well.

Bottle, 75cl. A two-finger light tan head sits on top of a black body. Nice lacings. The aroma is pretty bourbon-ish, but with a lovely coffee and dark chocolate as a foundation. Roasted, almost charcoal-ish. It¬ís full-bodied and warming, with a very soft carbonation level. The flavor has a distinct bourbon flavor in the background, with lots of coffee and a delicious taste of high quality dark chocolate. Really long finish. I prefer the regular edition, but putting it on bourbon barrels for a while isn¬ít the worst idea. 130819

Bottle, courtesy of womencantsail. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma of molasses, chocolate, bourbon, caramel and roasted grains. Flavor is sweet an malty with some molasses, coffee, vanilla, oak, warming alcohol and chocolate. Full body, soft carbonation.

Bottle 750ml @ Motel Room, Motel 6, Kingman, AZ
[Courtesy of womencantsail] Pours pitch black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, licorice, oak, vanilla and alcohol. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter with a long warm, roasted, chocolate, coffee, vanilla and oak finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Bourbon aroma with a hint of coffee. Nice thick body with great roast bourbon flavor. Great beer.
Pours black brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is sweet warming booze vanilla coco and toffee. Taste is sweet bitter with burnt sugar vanilla wood toffee. Palate is full syrupy warming and dry.

On tap at Alesmith tasting room. Jet black with minimal brown head. Nose is bourbon and a hint of cough syrup. Taste of chocolate, raisins and cough syrup. Finish is pretty darn smooth. Needs more age.

Bottle; Pour is murky dark brown with a fine bubbled khaki head in this glass; this one inch head retains on the average side, eventually hazing and ringing this glass - spotting is quite light - the nose is dark fruit, barrel treatment, chocolate morsels, coffee bean, and modest bourbon - the flavor profile reveals the most palatable 12% bourbon barrel aged imperial stout I¬íve ever head - I¬ím so gracious to be able to try this one on my birthday today - thanks dan! Initial flavor profile reveals more chocolate morsels, cake, bittering coffee bean, moving to barrel treatment, bourbon barrel, and finishing with raisin, plum, vanilla, and booze - Loved it.

Bottle, approximately three years of age, shared with guests at my fortieth birthday celebration. Full-bodied, rich flavors, added interest from the oak vanillins, this is certainly exceptional -- though maybe not as exceptional as I had been expecting. Other top-end non-BA imperial stouts (darkness,abyss,speedway) are in the same ballpark.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2013 Bottle at a tasting, pours deep black with small to med off white head, sporadic lacing. Aromas and flavor, of rich and luxurious bourbon barrel, vanilla bean, licorice, and milk cocoa. Silky smooth palate, I don¬ít know how they restrained the alcohol so well in this one...ridiculous.

Bottle at Sour & Bitter #2. Black with a small good lacing beige head. Bourbon, dark chocolate, molasses, warming alcohol, sweet roasted malt. Taste is heavy sweet and medium bitter. Full body, fat creamy texture, soft carbonation. Soft, soft, smooth, smooth.

Had on tap at Alesmith brewery in San Diego. Outstanding stout from taste and mouthfeel to aroma. Appearance is midnight in a glass and drinks like a boss. Delicious.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2015 Thanks mike! New Bohemia bottle share, going strong! 2009 bottle. Mike hired a bunch of homeless guys, paid them $10 an hour to sit in line, and ended up with a bunch of bottles - crazy! Big black pour with a tan head. Bourbon nose that finishes with some nice coffee. Smooth, thinner than expected. Really nice. A fun sipper for sure!

Edit: had a more recent vintage on draft at the brewery two weeks ago and it really stood out.

never thought i¬íd ever get to try this, ever- thanks to daniel for
setting us up with a bottle .. . black brown .. . quite complex .. . 
booze, tar, gold, vapors, mild barrel .. . silky and full .. . 
very enjoyable beer .. . . poking people in the eye is not quite cricket.

Pours almost black. Lots of aromas, let it breathe a bit and its keeps developing. Bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, almost a slight fruity something?
After a year in the cellar.... Worth the wait. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle thanks to artmcd8. Poured black with minor light tan foam. Very strong bourbon aroma with slight coffee. Quite smooth bourdon roasted flavor.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2013 Black foil 2012 bottle. Shared with charule and his lady. Pours a deep black with a brown head. Aroma of bourbon and chocolate. There is a slight hint of vanilla. The taste is extremely smooth. No heat whatsoever. A slight bitter finish with some spiciness from the alcohol. Amazing all around.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

End part of a 750ml bottle, thanks to brew3crew for sharing. Gold printed-on label. Black color. Good thin brown head. Few splotches of lace. Awesome big bourbon nose. Vanilla, chocolate, charred oak, coffee all play very nicely in the aroma. Bigger body. Velvety smooth, chewy texture. Very light carbonation. Awesome long coffee aftertaste, some vanilla. Moderate bitter taste, some alcohol heat in the flavor. Very light bite in the finish. Love the aftertaste on this. Lots of roast coffee, some dark chocolate, and barrel character. Rich dark malts; brownie-like. Very tasty, big, complex stuff.
This beer is amazing.  Great color, great aroma, great palate, great flavor.  Reminds me of BB4D.  My favorite Speedway variant so far.  Have yet to try Vietnamese or BA Kopi, though.

Bottle @ S&B#2. Pours black with a lasting and good lacing dense light brown medium head. Aroma is very malty with roasted malt, dark sugar, hops!, coffee, oak, coconut, brown sugar and sweet licorice. Taste is near heavy sweet and medium+ bitter. Body is near full, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft. Finishes bitter and roasted with a distinct alcoholic burn. Seems more sweet and less poised than the regular. Very nice though.

ZEBF13
pours black/brown . fast fading foam. 
very much bourbon in the smell. 
rather light carbo. realy heaty alcohol. sweet, bitter, chocolate in the very late aftertaste. i prefer the regular way more
Poured very dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma of roast malt and dark chocolate. Full body, flavour as the aroma with some bourbon hints from the barrel.

Very dark brown, small tan head. Rich bourbon aroma, raisins, woody, milk chocolate. Thick, complex. Looses some roast. Bit boozy, not too much, but lots of character. Amazing but like the original even better. (ZeeBra)

Oh god. On cask at the brewery, served slightly warmer than all the other beer. Aroma is a huge woody barrel punch, with the coffee and roast malt coming in behind. Amazing bourbon wood taste but without a hot bourbon mess like so many others. Terrific creamy beer that I can't even describe.

Cask at Alesmith.
Aroma: cocoa, fudge, coffee, mellow roast malts, well integrated notes of spirits and oak, toffee and some malt sweetness. 
Appearance: jet black, opaque, presistent brown head with little lacing.
Taste: coffee and caramel, nice roasty notes, lots of chocolate, mellow sweetness, pleasant notes of spirits and charred oak, low bitterness but enough to balance, alcohol is almost imperceptible and comes through as a slight warmth in the finish.
Palate: full body, low and creamy carbonation,  exceedingly smooth. 
Overall: wow, so well balanced and easy to drink, just fantastic.
Black, tan head. Nose is big bourbon barrel, chocolate, roasted malts. Taste is very bourbon forward, wood, chocolate. Pretty thin mouthfeel.
Excellent stout. Particularly great with a slice of chocolate cake :) Nutty chocolaty refreshing taste.

Bottle. [thanks bluebetty]
[vintage 2009]
Tasted next to a 2010 regular Speedway. Pours opaque black with a small, creamy brown head. Aroma has vanilla, roasted malts, fat chocolate, apples, quite vinious. Low carbonation, fat and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has coffee, vanilla, roasted malts, chocolate, vinious notes and plums. Very nice.
Bottle from 2009. Pours pitch black with a small cappuccino colored head. Aromas of coffee, vanilla, sweet licorice and toffee. Sweet and roasted flavor. Tasty.

March 16, 2013 - bottle via trade.  Black pour with some head that faded quickly and spotty lacing.  You could tell the aroma of the base beer was there, but also had some nice bourbon.  Taste was consistent with aroma, but a touch too sweet in the taste and finish.  A little bit thinner than the Kopi version, but still a really good beer.

Thanks to Ryan, great chocolate pour with a tan head. Aroma is big time woody barrel scents with vanilla notes, taste is similar with some nice coffee undertones, outstanding beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber. Super dark pour. Lots.of bourbon on the aroma and taste. Very rich. Delicious.

Probably the best coffee stout I've ever had! Bitterness is incredible and unexpected, and the coffee flavor is just enough to remind you that this is still a brew. Mouthfeel is medium, alcohol is high, and the carbonation is low to medium.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This might be my favorite desert beer ever. I get tons of dark chocolate, coffee and the mouthfeel is so creamy and delicious.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 feb 2013, bottle. Dark brown/black w almost red edges. Nose is huge sweet bourbon stout, big alcohol, winey. Wow. Med body and mildly fizzy. Thin oily finish. Burnt dry oatmeal, some coffee, granola, sugary maple syrup, moderate alcohol. Great!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Review #650. 750 ml bottle served in a CCB snifter. 2012 vintage

A: Pours a very dark black color with a tan head forming on the pour. It recedes quickly to thin ring that leave some minor sploches of lace behind.

S: Bourbon up fron couple with some figs and various dark fruit. Sweet barrel presence with some caraml and light vanilla. A little stone fruit sweetness with some roasted malts and chocolate.

T: The barrel is upfront with some oak and smooth bourbon. Bakers chocolate and some milk chocolate with heavy roast. I¬ím missing the coffee flavors from this guy, but it¬ís still really good.

M: Silky smooth mouthfeel, medium to heavy bodied. Medium carbonation level.

O: This is definitely in the upper echelon of BA stouts. Having more coffee notes would have definitely set it apart. Still a very delicious brew that I¬íd love to have again.

Serving type: bottle

2012 vintage poured into a tulip. Adam Jackson shares another top quality brew from his cellar with me. Opaque black in color with thin tan head. The head dissipates to a soapy ring. In the nose its nearly completely bourbon. DAMN, lots of whiskey. Taste is chocolate, oak, some strong bourbon notes. Mouthfeel is full with plenty of booziness. Soft carbonation. Overall this stout REALLY needs to sit and mellow. i feel we did a great injustice in drinking this so young. I¬ím still happy to have tried it but... if you have to trade for it, and most people will, I wouldn¬ít give up a lot because you can find other BA stouts that are just as great. I¬ím sure after some sitting this would be amazing.

Late 2012 Release. Enjoyed in a wine glass at room temp with Chris.

A -  Poured a heavy oily black. Very big 3 finger espresso colored head that faded to nearly nothing

S - Nose is as expected. Not as boozy as BCBS but very much big on vanilla, dark chocolate and espresso beans with a hint of campfire. 

T -  Loads of boozy bourbon charred oak alcohol at the front. Middle is dominated by vanilla and toasted walnuts and caramel. Finish is all oak..just smokey and oaky and big. I get a hint of off-flavors like cheap candies and smoke but it¬ís not too bad. 

M - Heavy body, swishable carbonation, nice and boozy and almost a champagne like finish with some stickiness of coffee beans.

O - This is a top 50 stout? It¬ís great and I¬ím going to rate it appropriately but I don¬ít see this as a HUGE whale of a stout on RateBeer. Drinkable, delicious but bourbon county is about 80% of what this is and far more accessible. If this was on the shelf next to BCBS, I¬íd grab it but it¬ís not worth the limited release and regional availability to seek it out.

Perfect aroma of coffee and chocolate and brown black pour with a constantly changing taste and soft mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750 ml bottle to oversized snifter (newest vintage, shared with the Mrs.; thanks darkmoon66). Looks good; black with foamy tan head that dissipates into lacing fairly quickly. Smells delicious; dark malt, chocolate, coffee, and bourbon with vanilla notes (likely from the barrel treatment). Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel. This is world-class!

2012 vintage, poured from a bomber into a tulip.  Pours opaque black with a small head, much smaller than the non BA version.  Nose is bourbon, vanilla and coffee.  Taste is sweeter than the non BA version, and follows the nose, with some coconut in there.  Definitely less coffee-heavy than the non BA version.  Great mouthfeel.  Delicious.

Wow,  What a smooth and easy drinking 12% beer.  The barrel notes are soft and complimenting with notes of vanilla, light spice, dark fruits, and chocolate. The base beer is less robust and powerful then regular speedway which is a good thing.  Everything about this beer from the aroma to the taste to the palate is smooth subtle and nice.  Loved it.
Big thanks to Justin, wow this is awesome. Subtle light barrel and beer characteristics, this is great

2009 bottle. A nice scent of malts, roasted barley, vanilla, brown sugar, coffee, bourbon, yeast notes, and dark fruit. I taste roasted chocolate malts, a slight to mild bourbon, coffee, yeast notes, oak, and dark fruit. It has a minimal dryness that fades and leaves a malty finish. Overall this is tasty. A very relaxing brew.

I had the 2011 just a few weeks ago with another friend of mine. We both agreed that the beer is an awesome beer and well worth the ranking it recieves. The bourbon smell hits you first and as you sip the beer the vanilla and coffee aromas become more detectable. This beer is very complex and considering the alcohol content I do not detect it in the mouth, instead I got it as a slight burn down deep in the throat. The beer is silky smooth in the mouth and each time you taste you can focus on a new flavor. The bourbon gives you a bite upfront but then quickly disapates so you can taste the caramel, vanilla, coffee, and chocolate in the beer. Something I hope to get ahold of again one day but when I do I am not so sure I will want to share

Bottle at The Stout Tasting Part I, London - huge thanks to Paul for providing this big fella. Vintage 2009. Pours black-brown with a rich, brown cream head. Classic dark malt nose, hints of coffee, light roast, sugary chocolate. Medium to big sweet flavour with smooth and silky chocolate notes, some alcohol presence, mellowed roast. Full bodied with fine to average, creamy carbonation. Warmin finish with more silky chocolate, moderate roasted malts, vague coffee. Very smooth and drinkable.

750 ml. bottle.  Thanks Peter!!  Pours a true black with an average reddish tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, vanilla, bourbon, and chocolate.  Taste is roasted malt, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, dark fruit, and wood.  Excellent balance.  Truly amazing.

2009? Bottle @ THE Stout Tasting. Thanks to Scopey for picking this up on his raid of the west coast! The pour¬ís deep brown with a medium, thick tan head. Classic appearance. Handsome. The nose is very full rich coffee, vanilla. Plenty of wood and roasted cocoa. Smooth, sweet aromas. The taste is more strong coffee. Sweet vanilla and sticky chocolate cake. Maple syrup oatmeal, toffee. Hot finish. Full body, rich, thick. Overall, pretty excellent. A bit rough ¬ín ready, but very tasty.

2009 bottle acquired by trade, consumed at THE stout tasting - part 1. It pours near black with a medium tan head. The nose is coffee, roasted malt, oak, vanilla, coconut, chocolate, lactose, liquorice and mild acidity. The taste is roasted malt, wood, coffee, light acidity, vanilla, milk chocolate, vanilla, toasted coconut, liquorice, bourbon, light alcohol warmth and earth. Full body, fine carbonation and not cloying at all. Smooth, well balanced and mighty drinkable. I wouldn¬ít say it¬ís massively complex, but it¬ís delicious.

Chilled 75 cl 2009 brown bottle poured into a snifter at a JStax tasting.  Pours coal black with light brown head.  Little lacing, medium body, light carbonation, and wonderful strong bourbon aroma.  Taste is bourbon, chocolate, and a hint of salt.  The bourbon taste hit me hard to start with, but really enjoyed this the more I drank.

2009 vintage. Pours black with a khaki colored head of foam that dissipates at a moderate rate. Aroma has a dry maltiness to it. Big bourbon on the nose and a bit gravelly at cooler temperatures. As it warms, that goes away. Taste is very sweet, there¬ís an ever so slight tartness, and a bourbon presence that has less of a presence than the nose indicated. Very complex taste. Kind of dry on the tongue. Very mellow and delicious.
Outstanding beer here. Such a balance of coffee, cocoa, bourbon, and oak. Liquid goodness.

This bottled brew from rbsg 2010 #58 poured a head of dark brown colored bubbles that were fully diminished and left behind a no visible carbonation opaque dark brown colored body and a oily lacing. The aroma was dark malt and bourbon. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The strong flavor contained notes of roasted malt and vinous. Delicious and one I would certainly like to have again.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter.  Pitch black with a khaki head.  The aroma of this beer is incredible.  It smells like a dark chocolate caramel vanilla dessert.  This is probably the best smelling beer I¬íve ever had.  The taste is very well balanced. Just enough bourbon. You can taste the underlying stout, but the vanilla bourbon is still present.  There is just a tinge of coffee bitterness on the finish. If it didn¬ít say it had coffee in it, i probably wouldn¬ít have realized it, but you did get a bit of coffee in the finish.  Don¬ít expect this to be a coffee beer, because you will be disappointed if that¬ís what you¬íre after. The coffee is a subtle component in a wonderfully crafted and balanced bourbon barrel aged imperial stout. Incredible beer.

2012.  Coffee gets hidden and should be more forward.  Pretty boozy, though its overall complexion is nicely crafted and refined.  Far superior to the ¬í09 bottles I¬íve had, also better than the ¬í03.  Should age well.  Best vintage yet IMO.
Really thick, with a chocolatey coffee-like flavor. Not as much tones of barrel-aging as expected or desired, but overall a very good Imperial Stout!

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2014 A - pours opaque cola brown with 1 finger dark brown head that dissipates. S - very mellow rounded stout aromas. Bitter chocolate, toffee, vanilla, molasses graham crackers. Hints of soy sauce. M - nice well rounded very smooth rich velvety mf. Full palate, nice soft warming on the end. T - dry oakiness, nice espresso, bitter chocolate up front. Molasses, toffee, vanilla, richer chocolate/coffee on the palate. Nice warming. Lingering chalky, brown sugar, earthy notes, soy sauce. O - amazing well rounded warmed. Fantastic and complex. 8 ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2013 2012 bottle. Color of dark coffee with a oily sheen of a head. Slight bourbon nose (less boozy than I expected) with some anise and charred oak. For the taste, subtle burnt sugar, light oak, malty biscuit, with the slightest touch of coffee at the end. Almost no booze tones from the bourbon, just a residual sweetness. One of the smoothest palates I¬íve tasted, but with a slight gritty finish. Well made, but I would have liked just a bit more boozy, bourbon flavor.

2012 release of bourbon barrel-aged speedway stout. Aroma is thick with bourbon notes followed by a dark coffee and chocolate richness. The appearance is as dark as beers come with a thick mocha head that retreated much more slowly than expected for a 12% stout. The taste is very complex. Vanilla is a strong flavor but far and away the bourbon and coffee flavors are the centerpiece of the beer. Overall I love this beer. Bring friends to share a bottle with if you manage to get your hands on a bottle. It is a rich, thick beer that is best enjoyed slowly as it warms.

2009 bottle from JohnnyJ in trade. Aroma of bourbon, signature Speedway-Ryan Bros, and deep, dark chocolate. Flavor was much of the same with more Ryan Bros that the others, but only slightly. I can't say enough about how smooth this one is from start to finish...simply amazing. I now understand the exquisite balance, palate, and experience. One of the most amazing beers I've ever had. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2009 bottle, poured a dark black color, aromas of chocolate, molasses, bourbon, oak, vanilla, some coffee, and a touch of roasted malt.  Flavors follow the aromas, blended nicely.  The chocolatey fudge paired well with bourbon, and the vanilla flavors were nice as well.   An extremely nice stout that I am glad I shared with some friends.
Poors black as tar, taste like coffee and dark bakers chocolate, the mouthfeel feels like milk chocolate. Great perfectly balanced beer.

Bottle, merci Phil! Nice black pour, thick brown foam. Aroma of chocolate, rich molasses (typical Alesmith), alcohol, light bourbon (really light IMO). Taste is chocolaty, bourbon vanilla, toffee, a very very light hint of coffee, boozy finish. Palate is slightly hot, but right on the mark for the warming alcohol feel, a real sipper of an imperial stout, it coats the mouth and never seems to leave. A huge beer, absolutely delicious.

Bottle 750ml [2009] Thx JulienHuxley.
Pours very dark brown/black with very low beige head. Intense lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, oak, caramel. Taste is of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, bourbon, alcohol (burning). Bitter finish. Palate: fair body. Overall: Very good. Pretty complex, but very boozy. Lots of alcohol in there.

Bottle (750 ml) 2009. Share by JulienHuxley, thanks Julien & Pier-Luc! Black with a small long lasting beige head and some lacing. Aroma of bourbon, caramel, toffee, vanilla and wood. Similar to the regular Speedway Stout, with coffee replaced by bourbon. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a perfect amount of bourbon, caramel, toffee, vanilla, chocolate, liquorice and dark fruits notes. Smooth mouthfeel with a pleasant warming/burning alcohol. Like most Alesmith beers, the balance is absolutely perfect and this one is even more complex than the regular version. It¬ís really the kind of beer I want to have on hand when returning from snowshoeing on a cold winter day.
Taste of a typical stout. Maybe a bit to dry, but absolute worth trying. Smoke and licorice are some if the caractiristic flavours

Speedway has always been a fave - Coffee Stouts are the beer that really got me going as a brewer, and this and Beer Geek really hit the spot.   The Dry end, with dry woody boubon.   

Shared in San Diego.
Poured from a 2009, 750 ml bottle, thanks to Jeremy. Huge notes of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, some hot notes, coconut. Very good, thanks for sharing.

Fat strong black ale with a beige thin head. Coffee and chocolate in nose with hints of vanilla and bourbon. Really complex and special beer....

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Black color with lasting tan head. Earthy dirt, vanilla, coffee, chocolate aromas. medium body. dark roast coffee flavors with dark chocolate, vanilla, mild dry wood--good not great
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
My stupid fucking phone lost most og this ratig, but here¬ís what I have recreated. 2009 bottle thanks to loverob. Aroma is heavy bourbon, buttery and oaky. Lots if malt sweetness, roasted coffee, dark fruits, vanilla and some charred oak. Gorgeous aroma, though a bit alcoholic from the barrel aging.

Taste is more lile regular Speedway Stout - bitter coffee, dark chocolate, hop bitterness and a very complex malt profile - then topped with some nice woody dryness and some bourbon influence. Low carbonation, viscous palate. I think I would prefer regular speedway, though.¬†9-3-8-3-17

Pours midnight black with med-sized head. Aromas, dark chocolate, toasted malts, faint smell of coffee. Flavor vanilla, mocha, dark chocolate, with very faint coffee hint/ undertone. Some bitter notes, dry chocolate like finish. Makes for a very solid Stout.
Chocolatey, coffee, decadent and rich.layers on layers of enjoyment. Best stout I¬íve tried yet...wowzer.

Bottle at Rooie Dop brew dungeon, courtesy of caesar, much appreciated for bringing this one along! Black colour, dark brown head. Nose is roasted malts, lots of coffee, vanilla, wood and bourbon. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee, slight vanilla, liquorice. Oily, slightly sweet finish. Delightful.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2013 Bottle √¢¬Ä¬ô09 - Pours black with dark brown head - Lots of bourbon and coffee with some vanilla in the nose - Lots of coffee, chocolate, and vanilla - really nice, smells and tastes great. This was a real treat. I need another bottle, badly!!!

This beer is even better fresh, which is why I decided to bump my score. This beer would be a 5 if not for the lack of viscosity, compared to Zhukov.

A-- Poured straight black. Nothing more, nothing else. Nice looking light brown two finger head that left a good collar of head once settled. Good spotty lacking left on the sides of the glass while drinking. 

S-- Coffee, chocolate, roast, oak, ABV and subtle bourbon. Coffee has held up well in the nose I thought. far better quality coffee than other BA stouts have used. 

T-- Bourbon, vanilla, Carmel, coffee, and chocolate. far bigger bourbon taste than the smell. Same with carmel. Far bigger and bolder taste than the nose. 

M-- Rich and luscious. Medium bodied and medium carbonation. Dangerously drinkable for the ABV, even with the alcohol being pretty obvious in this. My biggest want of all time and it did deliver on many levels. Yet not nearly as good as other BA beers. Still would trade for it again in a heartbeat or get homeless people to sit in line for it

75 cl bottle @ vPBF. 2009 vintage.
Pours pitch black color with medium-sized, steady beige head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, dark chocolate, dark toasted malts, some liquorice, faint salmiac and tar. Flavor of vanilla, dark chocolate, mocha, liquorice, very faint salmiac, tar, mild syrup and bourbon. Quite smooth palate, mild bitter notes, dry chocolaty finish. Excellent but I expected a bit more.
5427

750 ml bottle @ vPBF 2012. 2009 version.
Pours a black colour with a beige creamy head. Aroma of roasted malts, vanilla, . Really complex flavour just like in the normal Speedway Stout; roasted malts, vanilla, bread, bourbon, quite strong bitterness, dried fruits and lovely oakiness from the barrel. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a rich, malty, bready and oaky finish. Extremely well balanced and the barrel aging works as expected.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2012 75 cl bottle vintage 2009 @ vPBF. Huge thanks to tiong!
Aroma is sweetish with vanilla, some bourbon and woody notes.
Flavour is slightly sweet and syrupy with woody and bourbon notes, vanilla and some licorice. Becomes sticky rather fast and the bourbon notes are a bit too strong for my taste. A successful and balanced BA beer however.

Aroma is vanilla, liquorice, some roasted notes as well as some slight alcoholic notes. Flavour is vanilla, ripe fruits, alcohol, liquorice and some mild sherry notes.

Bottled 750ml (vPBF, vintage 2009)
Thanks tiong for sharing this. Oaky, vanilla, toasted malts and some alcohol in the nose. Full-bodied. Sweet vanilla, salted licorice, coffee beans, tobacco, some alcohol in the finish. Medicinal. Smooth palate. This is awesome, balanced and as good as reputation.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2015 750ml bottle from a trade, thanks stawn! @ vPBF

2009 vintage - Pours pitch black with a nice brown sticky and foamy head.Aroma of roasted malts, licorice, vanilla, oak, bourbon, hints of coffee and chocolate.Taste is slightly sweeter than the original Speedway Stout. Has a lot of roastiness, notes of vanilla, wood, oak, coffee and sweet molasses.Sweetish and smooth finish with nice bourbon vanilla notes and roastiness. Alcohol comes through slightly in the end. Overall a quite massive beer. Perhaps just a tad too sweet for my taste, though, and not as perfectly balanced as the original one. Still extremely tasty. 9-5-9-4-16

Re-rated on draught at AleSmith observation room, vertical with regular Speedway stout. Silky smooth, super complex and well balanced. Really tasty and alcohol is well hidden. Not much coffee here compared to the regular one. Just pure bourbon awesomeness.

Pours black with a medium mocha head.  Aroma has nice roasty dark fruit, bourbon, oak, vanilla, coffee...amazing.  flavor has great roasty dark fruit, coffee, cocoa...wonderful bourbon...mild oak...holy hell its good!  Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is oaky vanilla/coffee/bourbon...warming.  awesome!

Bottle 2009 thanks mcgrupp shared with Watson and my wife. Aroma of chocolate and bourbon barrel. Pours black very minimal tan head. Taste is medium body lots of coconut and vanilla very balanced with barrel

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2012 on tap at the brewery. Pours black with a small tan head. aroma is deliciously roasty, cocoa and bourbon wood. all balanced from aroma through flavor, heavy on the roast and bourbon but it fits well all around, plenty of cocoa, coconut wood and light char, all good character and complexity. rounded from start to finish. very good beer

Bottle, 2009 ed, courtesy GT2. What a going away gift! Ink black pour with a good tan head, some retention/lace. Aroma of coconut, chocolate milk, vanilla, light espresso. Taste is milk chocolate, vanilla, coconut, light roast. Fantastic palate: ultra soft, creamy, light warmth, rich chocolate finish.

Bottle 407/447 ¬í07 thanks to ygtbsm94: Poured a deep black with light red haze tint to the edge, the head was thin brown. Aroma was thick boozy aged fruit and malts that stuck to the nose, also chocolate and coffee notes. Taste seemed slightly mellow with nice chocolate cocoa, coffee, dark fruit, and malts. The finish remained boozy and hints of vanilla.  After adding another two years of separated from when I received this beer I hoped that the variables in aging wouldn¬ít hurt it. I¬ím safe to say this beer was drinking very well. I will make it a point to try any and all samples of this if presented with the chance.
Citrus, citrus, floral, floral, floral, floral, coffee, coffee, coffee, hay, coffee, floral

Thanks to Brad for sharing this at his tasting on Saturday!

2007 vintage. Bottle 212/447

This beer pours a rich, deep black with a dark tan head. Plenty of carbonation left in this gem. This aroma is not subtle. Bourbon and rich roasted malt, with a slight alcohol note emit huge scents I can detect from a few feet away. The beer is absolutely fabulous. Although it is very strong and forward, it drinks very smoothly. It definitely has some heat to it, but it only serves to add a little warmth in the finish. Alesmith Speedway Stout is a terrific beer, so it makes sense that barrel aging such a tasty stout would result in this masterpiece. What a treat.

Pours dark and black with a small brown head. Nose is toasted nuts, roasted coffee, vanilla, dates, plums and molasses. Taste is sweet with a heavy dose of bitter and a pinch of tart. Decadent. Mouthfeel is slick and oily. Big alcohol warming. Huge heavy body and a very long finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, huge thanks to tkrjukoff. Pitch black with a nice lasting brown head. Vanilla aroma, licorice, dades, figs, chocolate, peat, whisky, hay, cocoa, malt, roasted, tar notes, raisins, maily notes, hops, quite some bitterness. Roasted whisky flavor, woody, tar, licorice, dark chocolate, vanilla, dry, hoppy, metallic notes, figs, really heavy with a complex body, some alcohol but most of it is well hidden, peat, spicy notes, evident coffee that didn¬ít show during the first sips, mint notes. Smoked finish with pepper, cocoa, peat, dark chocolate and salt. Really good beer...

Bottle 75 cl, tnx to Greg. Pours thick pitch black with a great thick creamy briwn head keaving nice lacing. Aroma is fullbodied sweet slightly boozy vanilla dill dark fruits fidges acidy roasted malty; so good indeed. Flavor then, first sip is sweet acidy and fruity in front with a touch of alcohol. Middle section just keeps the first impression alive adding velvety sweetness vanilla dark fruits and some bitterness. Towards the end nice tingling feeling on tounge with all other flavors sustained and then suddenly peppery pungent feeling iver the back side of the tounge with coffee chocolate and licorice. Finishes bitter vanilla dill and roasted dry chocolate. Fantastic beer.

Beautiful beer. Inky black. Dark roast aroma. The flavor up front is all coffee, with a body that¬ís almost chunky. You can feel the coffee as much as taste it. It smooths out as it warms, lending itself to a complex layering of malt and roast flavors. Really nice.

Thanks to Deathcharms for this gem. This was on the top of my wants list after I first tried the original speedway stout. Here it goes. The nose was incredible with tons of bourbon and vanilla backed up with some chocolate, coconut, a touch of roast and more sweet vanilla notes. Wow. Such an inviting mix of aromas all balanced out to be equally noticeable. Pour is as expected. Black with a tan head. Viscous looking too. Taste wise there are lots of flavors I got from this. Obviously, there was a ton of bourbon and vanilla with chocolate, roast, raisin, molasses, and plum. No detection of alcohol at all. Such a good beer to just sit back and enjoy. Too good. Hopefully I¬íll get to try another vintage of this beer some day.

2009 vintage - Thanks to OmegaX, I finally got to try this beer. It looks just like the non-BA version but with a darker head. A first whiff reveals a huge bourbon boquet with a complex cherry and coffee aroma - vanilla is all over the place! The mouth feel is smooth and creamy. Notes of bourbon and oak tickle the senses. Undertones of milk chocolate, vanilla and mellow roasted coffee complete the well-defined layers of flavor. Obviously a sipper, the 12% is completely undetectable - truly a superb beer.

Poured into a snifter. 2009 vintage, which was released in 2011. 

4.5 A: Black color. Two fingers of creamy light brown head. Retention is very good for a brew this big and a sizeable ring of lacing is left.

4.5 S: As expected, there isn¬ít a whole hell of a lot of coffee left in this. There is some coffee, but it might just be coming from the base stout. Lots of chocolate and molasses. Caramel and a touch of smoke to follow. The bourbon is a bit softer than I was expecting, but I¬ím not disappointed since the base beer is more than solid. Leathery with melon and apple fruitiness. Light oak and enough vanilla to please.

4.0 T: The taste is very good, but it seems like the bourbon is now carrying the beer instead of the opposite found in the nose. Leather, vanilla, melon, smoke, light spiciness, oak, and bourbony booze predominate. Chocolate, molasses, caramel, and coffee from the stout. Don¬ít get me wrong, this is borderline 4.5.

4.5 M: Medium, borderline heavy body. Good moderate carbonation. Nice creaminess. No qualms here.

4.5 D: Very tasty beer, but I wish it was easier to get. It takes a lot to pull this in a trade, so in the future I¬íll resign myself to obtaining BCSs, CBS, and BA Boris. That said, I¬ím happy I traded for this because it is a great beer and something everyone should try.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-30-2012 22:16:48

@HallingHansen tasting, thanks for sharing. Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, liquorish, oak, vanilla and coffee. Flavour is roasted malt, alcohol, chocolate, liquorish, oak, vanilla and coffee.

Rating #2300. Vintage 2009, split with manuchampions and uhlan. Pours black with a small-to-medium light brown / tan head. Aroma of espresso beans, bourbon and wood, vanilla beans and not too boozy. Flavour is essentially just the regular Speedway Stout, but with a more prominent woody character - just as much espresso, but slightly obscured by the barrels and subtle vanilla quality. Finishes with vanilla and bourbon, and a slight boozy burn. Surprisingly easy to drink for a big barrel aged imperial stout. Delicious and superior to the original by a little bit. I¬ím glad I went out of my way to obtain this.

From notes.  

The full black color, long lasting tan cap, and high viscosity on BA Speedway definitely signals the brewers intention to make a thick, rich, and complex imperial stout.  

For me, there is too much bourbon in the aroma and flavor, stifling one of my favorite base beers.  The bourbon and oak actually dry out the mouthfeel and pull some of the smoothness out of the flavor.  Chocolate, bitter roasted malt, and a little bit of coffee step in behind the bourbon.  It is a little bit acrid at the end of each sip.  As it warms up a little bit, I get some vanilla, oak, and milky sweet notes.  I would suspect that some of the off-putting bitter coffee and malt notes and the acrid mouthfeel come from the old coffee.  Since this was a 2009 bottle, the coffee has significantly faded and could have left behind the old coffee taste that I have observed in a number of aged coffee stouts.  

BA Speedway is still enjoyable nonetheless, but this bottle does not do justice to how delicious fresh Speedway Stout is.

2009 vintage, big thanks to Pat for the trade.

The smell is just wonderful. Bourbon presence but not overpowering. Very sweet vanilla mixing with the bourbon and some good amounts of coffee make this smell outstanding. The taste is really smooth and adds up with the nose. There is the marshmallow character that only comes out in the best of barrel aged beers and the vanilla. The coffee is there but its not overpowering. It taste like a dank day old press coffee and its killer! I need another bottle of this for sure.

Bottle with friends. We tasted 2003, 2005, and 2011 vintages. This is a slight combination of all, but mostly reviewing the newest vintage. Deep brown appearance with a dark brown head. Sweet, dark, toasty chocolate malty, woody, black licorice aroma. Sweet dark chocolate, vanilla, marshmallow, oaky, sweet licorice flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2012 6/III/2012 75cl bottle @ De Hopduvel (Gent) - 2009 vintage (2012-217) Thanks to BoBoChamp for sharing the bottle!
Very dark brown beer, no head. Aroma: very vinous, red wine, caramel, mocha, vanilla, sour berries, ripe cherries, bourbon. MF: no carbon, medium to full body. Taste: mocha and coffee, bourbon, red wine, caramel, dark chocolate, dried red fruits, vanilla, alcohol. Aftertaste: more vanilla, bourbon, caramel, dark chocolate, dried red fruits, vanilla, alcohol. Aftertaste: more vanilla touches, bourbon, dark caramel, coffee, some liquorish, red wine, bit sugary, cocoa powder. Pretty impressive stuff. Wouldn¬ít be able to finish a pint, though.

I said it would never happen, that nothing would ever beat the J&J Oude Gueuze Blauw. But it happened. This is the perfect beer for me. I feel like a bit of a wanker, because I¬íd like to be all effete, and pretend that I¬ím "so past Imperial Stout" but FUCK ME THIS WAS AMAZING!!! First off, huge thank to nbutler11, who remembered from a drunken conversation at RBWG that the BA Speedway was my most-wanted beer, and then sent me one, not asking the moon, but rather "just send me something". Thats... That¬ís just something I don¬ít have words for right now... It would be like generous, but generous isn;t even in the same league... here to begin with this one: Pours Opaque black, Opqaue deliberatey capitalized back there becuse light CANNOT pierce this stuff.  The head is a very persistent dark tan, which just lingers, and lingers... Nose is creamed coconut, brandy beans, not even a suggestion of alcohol, just loads of vanilla, fresh-roast coffee, and layers of chocolate. Flavours are rather stunning as well: In my handwritten notes, I use the word "unfathomable" which I¬ím fairly certain is a first. Cream, cocoa, coconut, fudge, toasty barrel, French toast. I really never thought I would be so sure about a beer as to give it a 5, but here we are. "0The celestial ejaculate upon the bosom of Heaven." This is also in my handwritten notes. Underlined. Twice.

09 bottle. Big thanks to Lagunitasfan for opening this whale with me! I was worried at first because it gushed slightly upon opening, but the aroma that filled the room set me at ease. Of course it poured black with a dark brown head and the aroma was absolutely spot on awesome. Big time dark chocolate fudge, wood, bourbon, nuts, vanilla, cherry and only hints of coffee. The flavor was deliciously fudgy, nutty with great bourbon influences. Subdued vanilla, caramel and alcohol with a slightly noticeable astringency that I imagine comes from the coffee. Rather than distract, this only adds a little kick and brightens up the beer a bit. It gets a bit sweeter toward the end with a hint of cherry. Overall, I was not disappointed. For me, this is one beer that actually lives up to the massive hype. Thanks again Tim!

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2014 75cl, Vintage 2013, exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex Stout, roasted/alcoholic and slightly woody/spicy, not too heavy, balanced, hazy, good head, top class!, yet very expensive!
Una delle imperial stout meglio bilanciate al mondo, messa in botte suppongo di bourbon. Tanta vaniglia, caff√® e cioccolato, alcolica e potente.

So this is a beer I had March of 2010. I haven¬ít been on RateBeer much the past two years because of some life changes. Regardless, I thought I had rated this beer, but apparently I hadn¬ít. This beer was phenomenal. I had this along side with Russian River Pliny the Younger. My God I was in Heaven. Completely different from the PtY, but every bit as good.  Strong, but smooth coffee flavor and aroma, with hints of oak and chocolate.  Super creamy.  Just incredible.

Bottled sample via Savvy1982. Shared with oakbluff and Savvy1982. Jet black in colour with moderate carbonation. Potent yet well balanced aromas of roasted malts, cooked sugar, bourbon barrel, vanilla, and a hint of espresso. Huge coffee, dark chocolate and caramel goodness in the mouth, backed by more whiskey and herbal hops. Heavy mouthfeel, but surprisingly clean finishing. A fantastic beer.

At HallingHansen Grand Tasting, thanks for sharing. Pours a pitch black beer with a chocolate head. The aroma is malt, licorice, chocolate, vanilla and wood. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is very smooth with sweetness. Overall a fantastic beer.

2007 Vintage, Bottle #402/447
Tasted in late November 2011 from a capped 750mL bottle shared by unclejedi at his birthday tasting, infinite thanks, Jim.  Pours opaque oily black with an average tan head that leaves an average collar of lace.  The nose is super darkly roasted with some dark earthy notes, dark chocolate, coffee, and vanilla barrel underlying.  The flavor is showing some oxidation with toasted hazelnut, with the darkly roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and coconut/vanilla.  The body is full with average carbonation and a long roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and vanilla finish.

Reviewed from notes. 2009 vintage poured into a tulip I believe. The beer is pitch black in color with a light brown head and is completely opaque in transparency. The head dissipates to a soapy ring.  In the nose, I get milk chocolate, some light smoke, light oak, and very faint bourbon. Nothing here really stands out to me, pretty meh overall.  Taste follows the nose, chocolate, oak, some light bourbon, and malt round out the flavor profile.  Mouthfeel was light, almost a little watery in fact. Not much in terms of carbonation. No booziness and it finishes decently.  Overall this was a disappointment. In comparison to some of the other mammoth stouts that were sampled alongside this, this fell flat.  Hard pressed to see why this has received such accolades.

Bottle 2009 vintage. Trade from Sean9689, thanks man. Black body with a small offwhite head. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt, bourbon, alcohol. Flavor is chocolate, light alcohol, coffee, vanilla, oak, bourbon. Very complex. Nice lacings. Great beer.

Black with a small tan head. Aroma of coffee and roasted malt, with hints of licorice and vanilla. Sweet dark flavour of coffee, licorice, roasted malt and caramel, with a touch of alcohol. Hints of oak before a slightly ash finish

Bottle @ Hallinghansens US Tasting, Odense. 2009. Pours dark black with a creamy beige head and lacings. Oak, vanilla, coffee roast and chocolate. Smooth and soft. Harmonic and balanced. Straight forwarded - truly incredible drinkability. Really tasty. This ain¬ít even hyped! Wow!

Bottle at hallinghansen giant tasting. Hold da k√¶ft! Thanks Jacob! Its pitch black with a creamy tan head. The aroma is coffee, vanilla, oak, toasted caramel, hard roasted malt and chocolate. The flavour is hard roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, coffee and light ash. Great balance.

Old Review from 2010.  Poured from a growler - BA Speedway pours well you guessed it, pitch black.  Not much head is formed.  Small lacing of tan head around the glass.  Now with a lot of barrel aged brews, you¬íre punched in the nose with whatever barrel the brew was aged in.  In this case it¬ís bourbon but you¬íre not really punched in the face by it here.  It¬ís definitely there but I feel like this might be the best mixture and balance I have ever seen in a barrel aged brew.  The bourbon didn¬ít have to fight with the amazing espresso, dark chocolate, vanilla, and molasses.  This is a complex brew but like I said this is the most balanced version of a barrel aged beer I have ever smelled.

Taste is just like the smell.  The bourbon might of been a little more active here but it¬ís still balanced pretty much perfectly.  The dark chocolate lingers on the palette but then the slighty burnt espresso comes in and washes it away.  The brew ends with vanilla, brown sugar, and some dark fruit.  I just can¬ít explain how damn nice this beer is.  If I had to drink one beer for the rest of my life this might just be it.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied, oily, and sticks on the lips.  Low carbonation, smooth, and creamy.
pours a dark brown almost black. Aroma is cocoa and coffee. Very thick palate and toasty coffee malt flavor followed by heat and molasses.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2013 HUGE thanks to Kramer for busting out one of my all time wants for us to try. 2004 Bottle, number 120 / 228.


A - Pours black as night with a nice one finger tall mocha colored head leaving light lace down the glass. Not the prettiest beer but it is stil plenty serviceable.


S - Smells of rich coffee, milk chocolate, vanilla, oak, and warm bourbon. For being seven, going on eight, years in the bottle this one has held up beautifully, still plenty of coffee to go around.


T - Starts off with a big dose of fresh brewed coffee slowly giving way to a mix of chocolatey sweetness, vanilla, oak, tobacco, and warm bourbon. Even with all those flavors going on it remains balanced, smooth and easy drinking. Finish has lots of dark roast, lingering on the pallet for some time. A touch of oxidation creeps in as it warms up but it doesn¬ít really affect the taste at all.


M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Full, smooth, feel with plenty of dark roast, lingering on the pallet for quite awhile after consumption.


O - Damn, this is easily one of the best Barrel Aged stouts I have ever had. The balance of dark flavors from the base beer blend flawlessly with the barrel aging to form one amazing beer. I can not thank to enough Kramer for the chance to try this one.

750ml bottle - Herring Creek beer tasting 

It¬ís been awhile since I had a beer this stunning. I¬íve had the opportunity to have the regular Speedway and it¬ís always a pleasure to consume, but this is a showcase of what barrel aging can do to an already fantastic beer. 

The beer pours out a basically perfect pour. At least a perfect pour to me. Completely black, dense light brown head, long lasting. An aroma just bursting at the seams with depth and complexity. Notes of bourbob, wood, anise, toffee, brown sugar, roastd malts, Tootsie Rolls, malt balls, milk chocolate, molasses...incredible. 

The flavor profile echoes the aroma, but the intensity of the flavor is unmatched. Alcohol is much more present in the flavor (as expected) than the aroma, but even then it mixes well with the other flavors. Everything is so damned well balaced it¬ís amazing. Mouthfeel is oily, creamy, dense. The beer just coats and clings to the glass and mouth like no other beer I¬íve had before. 

Simply put, this beer has everything that I want and look for in an imperial stout. It¬ís created amazingly well, and the time it spent in the bourbon barrel worked incredibly well. I cannot recommend this beer, if you can find it, enough.

Thanks to John for sharing this! Pours black as coal with a nice halo of brown head. Smell: bourbon, vanilla, coffee, tobacco, chocolate, licorice and some oak. Taste: coffee, vanilla, chocolate, bourbon, oak, big roasted notes, tobacco and licorice. Thick and chewy palate and a long roasted coffee and bourbon finish.

A deep dark stout with a thick dark brown head. In aroma, a smooth chocolate with light wooden notes, vanilla, dry and powdery coffee. In mouth, a beautiful smooth chocolate with light woody notes, coffee, very nice and balanced, very nice. Bottle from Boutip, shared with GRM, Probstk and Ian, Dec. 2 2011.

750 ml bottle shared by Boutip (merci!), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 02DE11.
App.:  Deep brown-black, deep mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Ashen, slightly green, spicy, peppery, chocolate, a little alcohol, a touch savoury, coffee notes, a bit of leafy hops, a touch rough and tough.
  
Palate:  Medium-full body, very relaxed effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Lots and lots of green, peppery coffee, chocolate, leafy hops, cocoa, big and huge, a little rough; sweet with high bitterness.

Zoom, zoom.  After 3 Jackie O¬ís and 3 Bourbon Counties, I might be a little jaded and spoiled.

Brown bottle, 1 pint 6 ounces, 2009, from Philippe Boutin, savoured on December 2 2011; eye: black, opaque, tiny ring of cappuccino head, light lacing; nose: cocoa, roasted barley, alcohol, vanilla, woody, dark chocolate, light alcohol; mouth: cocoa, roasted barley, alcohol, vanilla, woody, dark chocolate, alcohol warmth, short finale in roasted barley with presence of alcohol, full body, average carbonation, mildly sweet, lightly bitter, lightly alcoholic texture; overall: really good

FRAN√áAIS 

Bouteille brune, 1 pinte 9 onces, 2009, de Philippe Boutin, savour√©e le 2 d√©cembre 2011; ¬úil : noire, opaque, petit anneau de mousse cappuccino, l√©g√®re dentelle; nez : cacao, orge torr√©fi√©, alcool, vanille, bois√©, chocolat noir, l√©ger alcool; bouche : cacao, orge torr√©fi√©, alcool, vanille, bois√©, chocolat noir, chaleur d¬íalcool, finale courte en orge torr√©fi√© avec pr√©sence d¬íalcool, cors√©e, carbonatation moyenne, moyennement sucr√©e, l√©g√®rement am√®re, texture l√©g√®rement alcoolique; en r√©sum√© : tr√®s bon

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color stout with a medium size foamy head with minimal retention. Aroma of dry whisky with notes of dry roasted malt is interesting. Taste is a nice mix between some dry roasted malt notes with some coffee though not as much as in the original version with some dry whisky notes. Body is about average with medium carbonation and alcohol is not too apparent. A bit too dry and astringent for my taste thought still very much enjoyable.

(Bottle shared by Rusty at Black Friday tasting.  This was the 2003 edition and bottle 147/196).  Pours dark brown with red hues.  Aroma is wood oxidation and cocoa.  Taste is mostly sweet.  Thin bodied with a sticky texture.  Good, but definitely on the decline.

I gave my ratings on the most recent bottle, although my notes are not entered yet.

Pours dark chocolate solid in color with a nice caramel head. The aroma is mostly booze for me with a bit of dark fruits. The flavor is some chocolate roasted malts blended smoothly with the booze from the barrel aging and notes of the dark fruits.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2011 2003. Bottle 147. Very slight hiss upon opening. This is a bit past its prime certainly, but still awesome. Has held up quite well considering the age I¬íd say. Low carbonation. Nice booziness. Good coffee flavor. Exquisite Speedway palate and balance.

I love the barrel aged speedways. This is a 2003. The most recent 2011 I had was better (fresh) although I can imagine this beer being aged would be great! I do like having one way aged and one fresh to compare. There is not a lot of appearance as I would like from this style, but makes perfect sense with the age. Thanks for brining it to the tasting!!

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2012 Thanks once again to DT in the midwest.Opaque black pour good tan head aromas of bourbon caramel and rich coffee freshness some dark fruit molasses vanilla smoothness the flavours well now the main issue with alesmith is the balance between alcohol tastes hop malt bitter and sweetness and how all their ales are so smooth in taste this is no exception the bourbon is superb just so good expresso coffee dark chocolate molasses raisin and prune smooth vanilla tobacco mild velvety finish the bitter lasting along with some good maltiness hop fruit tastes and a resounding bourbon overtaste sweetness balanced a wonderful imperial

Bottle thanks to bsuedekum. Thanks a lot Blake! Pours thick and oily with a tan ring for a head. Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, chocolate. Flavor is coffee, chocolate and bourbon. Has a pretty sweet finish. Overall a very good beer.

I would say thanks to GT2, but my parents stood in line for this for him, so thanks mom and dad. Appearance is opaque, deep dark brown. Aroma is marshmallow, creme, chocolate pudding and hazelnut. There is also some graham cracker crust. Really great dessert aroma. Taste is bitter dark cocoa. There is some definite booziness in the finish, but not too much, some vanilla as well. Very well balanced. Palate is full bodied without being too thick and syrupy. Each element compliments the other quite nicely.

750mL 2009 ed. Ink black pour with a wildly active reddish tan head. Big lace for a BA beer. Nose up front is salty, briny, green olive, sharp gherkins. Volatile notes move to wildly awesome toasted coconut, milk chocolate, toasted coconut. Incredible umami savoriness in the nose. Taste is ultra soft, muted chocolate, lactic fattiness, and zero acidic coffee and lemon character which I despise in the normal Speedway Stout. This right here is a masterpiece. Muted barrel character, no heat, no booze. Just imperial stout perfection right here. Perfect palate: melted chocolate, chocolate pound cake, fatty yogurt, mild bourbon spice, buttery ganache. Holy fuck. An incredible experience. For one of the most stingy raters I can safely say this is totally worthy of its ranking and should be considered a god amongst men. Praise the lord for this beer.

A massive indebtedness for GT2 for hooking up with biggirlpanties whose parents actually camped out overnight to score this one for us - thanks to all!  Pours opaque brown black, massive brown head with fine and solid lacing with good retention. Aroma of vanilla, smooth melted dark chocolate, subtle edge of coffee. Taste is extremely smooth whiskey laced espresso soda with dark cocoa and a slightly boozy and chocolate syrupy finish. Fantastic.

800th rating!!  Bottle 2009.  Aroma has notes of bourbon, chocolate, molasses, espresso, oak, vanilla and roasted malts.  Black with a small fully diminishing brown head that left no lace.  Flavor is heavy sweet and medium bitter.  Palate is very full bodied and oily soft.  Overall a bourbon bomb that didn¬ít really impress like GI Rare did.  The nose is good but the flavor is overly sweet.  Glad I got to try it but would not go out of my way to get another.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2012 ¬í06 bottle drank in ¬í11, massive thanks Maltzilla! Tried it together with a fresh regular speedway. Wicked. Aroma is huge whisky oaky barrel goodness, spices, faint mocca coffee. Wow. Intense. Flavour is f#*%$g smooth creamy barrel oaky mocca madness. Did i say wow? LRAB

Bomber.  2009 version.  Dark pour but not pitch black.  Little to no head.  Nose did not seem as strong on the coffee when compared to the non BA version.  All of the usual suspects were there in vanilla, bourbon and wood.  Same with taste.  I tried this coming off of Black Tuesday and it still held up very well to that kind of competition.

Bottle at tasting, 2006 version. Side by side with a fresh regular speedway. Black pour, thin tan head. Aroma of leather, vanilla, oak, roasted malts. Flavor is extremely smooth, oaky, leathery, roasty, all in an amazing balance. Perfect balance, perfect body. Amazingly wonderful brew.

Poured from a 750ml bottle.  Pours black as night with a bit of brown head.  Aroma is coffee, some vanilla and a bit of bourbon.  Taste follows the nose.  I feel that the barrel aging does not add much to this beer, which is already pretty awesome.  We should have done a side by side for comparison, but I think it has just a bit more flavors of vanilla and coconut than the standard version.

2009 bottle from fleetwood. Dark viscous brown, almost black, brown beautiful crea,y head. Smooth bourbon, mild coffee, huge roasted malts and barley, great lacing all the way down the glass. Full bodied, creamy, coats the palate, mild but growing bitterness with some sweetness and booze. Bourbon is overwhelming though (may have benefited from another year on the shelf) but it does fade and leave a great complex finish - some bourbon, chocolate and coffee with a great malt profile. A very good beer.

Somehow the people over at Alesmith managed to Barrel age a serious stout without making the aroma massively influenced by the aging inside the barrel. It smells beautifully of Coffee, Chocolate, Malt and at the end, Wood, and it¬ís wonderfully subtle. The pour was dark like Ink and formed a speckled caramel colored head that was about a half inch thick but revealed no lacing on the glass. Possibly due to a substandard pour by me?

The beer taste was simply awesome. This high level seems consistent with Speedway. Every flavor from the Malt, to the chocolate and coffee are HUGE. That¬ís the amazing thing. There is almost nothing subtle about this beer, and at the same time, the wood and sweet flavors that finish the beer are light and linger on the palate. The beer is complex to be sure, but the flavors aren¬ít lightly floating around. They smack you in the face and it is better for doing so. Amazing beer. Thanks to Sean for trading me two 120 minute IPA¬ís from Dogfish for this beer. I feel like I got the better end of this deal.

Bottle shared by Dosbeerigos. What an incredible beer! Super dark and thick with a nice brown bubbly head. Aroma has hints of bourbon,chocolate,fudge,slight soy sauce etc. Heavy body but the flavors are intense. Would love to try this again.

Pours black with a full creamy head.  Beautiful lacing behind on the glass.  Vanilla, chocolate, caramel, toffee, bourbon, oak, and tobacco with a rich dark fruity character.  Anise, raisins, and dates come through but not overpoweringly.  Heavy chocolate and vanilla immediately are notable with a fine tobacco quality coming through as well.  Licorice, oak, and a ever slightly touch of char.  Nice warming finish with the alcohol not being notable till the finish.

Wow, lucky to have tried this. It is the latest batch brought over by Dan. Good to have a good friend,
Bacl as the ace of spades, with flavors that remind of roasty notes that are alot like dark 80% cacao chocolate, has that same roasted bitterness to it you find there. The coffee is approachable and integrated in a way that anyone could get into this. barrel notes are softer probally from the time. Excellent, great stuff. Bravo.

I can¬ít believe how good this is!  Thanks Dak.  2009.  Vanilla and burbon nose.  Very complex, lots of flavors.  Very well balanced leather, cigars, wood, choc, vanilla and burbon.  Not at all harsh, very smooth and silky.  I love it!

Appearance:  Pours a thick dark brown with a creamy tan ring of froth.

Aroma: Wood, Honey Smacks, strong bourbon, medium roasted coffee. Weaving in and out of any of these glorious aromas is alcohol.

Taste: Coffee, booze soaked barrel, dark roasted malt, burnt roasted malt. Finishes heavy on the bourbon.

Mouthfeel: Astringent, low carbonation, and very thick.

Overall:  A world class Bourbon Barrel Aged Stout.  This is one of the more bourbon forward barrel aged beers I¬íve had in a while, lots of wood and spirts to combat the huge malt and coffee profile.  I spent over an hour trying to put my finger on all that is going on with this beer.

had about 9 or 10 2oz taste of this fine 09 vintage at the release of the same beer jet black the og it smelled like cigar guts it was a super rusted nail w/ a bite yet smooth as a kitten very good beer @ 9am SWAG

Crushed with Jakebra and Honkeybra.  Bottle vintage 2007 #65/447.  Finally found an occasion to crack this bitch.  Had high expectations and she did not disappoint.  The bourbon was very apparent yet mellow at the same time.  Got some very interesting woody notes in the flavor, with a bit of sourness on the tongue.  Thick, silky, sexy.  An incredible experience drinking this beer.  Exhausting.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2017 Deutlich hefiger und ziemlich s√º√üer Malzantrunk, der ziemlich dicht wirkt. Der Eindruck verst√§rkt sich im Mittelteil, in dem die Malznoten sehr schokoladig sind.Im Hintergrund ist die Fasslagerung erkennbar, hier ist das Bier etwas holzig im positiven Sinne. Bitterschokoladig, stimmig und tiefgr√ºndig. Vollmundig, nie wird es hier langweilig. Ebenfalls sehr malziger Abgang, weich und harmonisch, sehr schokoladig. Vielen Dank an den Doppelbock f√ºr das Bier. -/13/11/13/-/13

3/5/2010 I shared my last bottle of this with a friend. 2006 Vintage.

Pours a solid black with a stingy tan head that dissipates quickly to a cap on top. Smells of coffee, vanilla, chocolate, dark fruits and prunes, with and oaky alcohol edge. The taste is filled with rich coffee and chocolates sprinkled with and oaky plum sweetness and a touch of alcohol. Hints of coconut and vanilla show up to the party but hide in the kitchen. Fairly thick body with a full creamy almost acridic mouthfeel and light carbonation. I am sad to say that I have enjoyed my last bottle of this fine brew. Intensely complex and damn tasty, I wish this was more available.
Don¬ít know much about beer, but this one is as good as it gets for a stout.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2014 appearance is opaque black, mocha thin lacing aroma is oak, chocolate, toffee, truffles, ash,  massive bourbon barreling, wood chips, treacle, syrup. Taste is chocolate chip cookies, toffee, burnt toast, smoke, ash, hot burn, booze booze booze, mental and worthy. Exceptiomal. I love coffee. I love beer.

A Mes rate. 2007 bottle no. 236/447 thanks hugely to Thomas. Legend.I¬íve had a sip of this a few years back and was bloody impressed, I¬íve been close to trying this a few times since but it¬ís always missed me for one reason or another. Now it¬ís here, I was worried I¬íd built it up to something too big in my head. One sniff made me think that wouldn¬ít be the case. One taste made me sure. It¬ís bloody excellent. Hugely wooden, like some bourbon and calvados soaked wood chips. Superb coffee character as always but it gels really well with the coconut. It has a hint of posh coffee accented dessert about it. Slight rubber in the nose holds it back a little if I¬ím going to be picky but not much. Glorious sour barrelly hints in the finish work beautifully. Slight marmite, not a full bodied as I was expecting. Excellent wood and caramel and coconut. God I¬ím loving this one. Can feel plenty boozy little worms making their way into my belly too. Ace ace ace. Worthy of the hype. At least, this bottle certainly is. All that said, it¬ís just too boozy to really enjoy.

2003 bottle sampled at RBSG 2010, truly a rarity - Pours black and smells mostly of bourbon along with chocolate and malts.  The carbonation is minimal.  It¬ís definitely mellowed.  It tastes sweet with the bourbon and chocolate blending smoothly together.  A smooth, full bodied brew with the alcohol buried after seven years of aging, it¬ís a superb beer and yet to me I think it have been even better a couple years earlier.
caramel, chocolate, coffee, roasty, intensely flavorful and full bodied beer

I got lucky enough to have this 2004 bottle at dld. The beer is black with a tan head, nothing remarkable here. The aroma is pretty nice, notes of oak, bourbon, and vanilla. The taste is what places this beer apart. Not sure if its because of the againg(2004), but there is beer simply taste phenominal. It was really sweet in a good way with tons of vanilla and chocolate and super smooth oak and bourbon. 

I¬íve since had this twice, 2003 & 2006.  This is awesome, but a touch to sweet for me to kill the bottle; must be shared.

This was an amazing beer.  Had a growler setting up for about 6 months.  Was a little difficult to open, but was well worth the effort.  The aroma of this amazing Stout really comes to life as it warms up to room temp.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2013 8th March 2009 Bottle 35/235 of 2006. Opaque black beer. Short lived tan head. Smooth and woody start followed by coffee malt and a fair bit of alcohol! Dry rich finish with coffee bitterness and more alcohol. Much better than the standard version! Complex to the point of being hard to pin down! 4th January 20132009 Bottle. THE stout tasting Pt1. Thanks to Paul for another bite of this big apple! Massive tan head Softish airy palate. Aniseed alcohol. Smooth dark malt. Mellow mild wood and vanilla. Mild smooth coffee. The alcohol is still a bit lively here, a tad too much so but still pretty good. 3.7

750 ml bottle shared by stefanje @ RBSG 2003 vintage.  Thanks Stefan!  Pours black in color with a very small tan head.  The aroma has all the good stuff working well together: chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, woody, well integrated bourbon and vanilla.  Very nice!  The flavor is full and rich and includes everything I would want in a big decadent imperial stout.  Roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, vanilla, coffee, wood, molasses and the well integrated bourbon.  There is no "I" in team, and these flavors are definitely working together.  This was one of my favorites of the evening.

I¬íve tried a number of 2006 vintages over the years.  Recent one was perhaps a little past its prime.  Fantastic woody imperial stout aroma.  Poured flat and black...not as thick as regular speedway.  Taste was hurt by a little soy.  Still a great beer.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2012 750 ml bottle.  Courtesy of dmsohyea.  Thanks.  2009 vintage.  Pours a pitch black with a small light tan chocolate head that has decent retention and leaves a good amount of lacing on the glass.  The aroma is big coffee, dark chocolate, a bit of bourbon, vanilla, and some oak.  The taste has a bit of sweetness with lots of coffee, vanilla, a bit of bourbon, some oak, and hint of cherry.  The finish has slight hint of alcohol, a bit of cherry, and a bit of bitterness.  It has the full, creamy mouthfeel that regular speedway has with low carbonation.  Amazing beer.  This was quite similar to regular speedway (which I love) with some added flavors and complexities from the barrel.  The only thing that could improve it would just a tad less sweetness, but other than that I have no complaints.
10.5.9.5.18

750 ml bottle generously shared by colonelforbin.  Thanks Mike.  2007 vintage.  Pours black as night with close to no head and no lacing on the glass.  The aroma is tons of dark chocolate, a decent amount of alcohol, some cherry, plum, and a hint of coffee.  The taste has a light sweetness, with some coffee, cherry, plum, The finish has some alcohol and a bit of bitterness on the finish.  Full bodied, but not quite as creamy as regular speedway.  Low carbonation.  A great beer, but quite a different beast than the 2009 BA Speedway (drank side-by-side).  The coffee was faded in this one (unsurprisingly) and it had quite a bit more alcohol present (somewhat surprising).  The cherry and fruit came through a bit more in this vintage.  Not quite as good as the 2009 vintage.
9.5.9.4.18


On tap at the Toronado Stout Festival.  2008 vintage, I believe.  Pours a dark black with a little bit of light coming through at the edges.  A small chocolaty tan head leaves a decent amount of lacing on the glass, much like the regular Speedway Stout.  This beer was served relatively cold and at first seemed like another pretty good imperial stout.  The aroma was vanilla, a little dark chocolate, and some bourbon with the taste very similar to the aroma.  Once the beer warmed up some it turned into easily one of the best beers I¬íve ever had.  The aroma is dark chocolate, vanilla, cherry, plum and dark fruits, dark roasted coffee, bourbon, and a little alcohol.
